trans-unit.source: Class std::chrono::high_resolution_clock represents the clock with the smallest tick period provided by the implementation. It may be an alias of std::chrono::system_clock or std::chrono::steady_clock, or a third, independent clock.

Class std::chrono::steady_clock represents a monotonic clock. The time points of this clock cannot decrease as physical time moves forward and the time between ticks of this clock is constant. This clock is not related to wall clock time (for example, it can be time since last reboot), and is most suitable for measuring intervals.
Class std::chrono::system_clock represents the system-wide real time wall clock.

Class std::codecvt encapsulates conversion of character strings, including wide and multibyte, from one encoding to another. All file I/O operations performed through std::basic_fstream<CharT> use the std::codecvt<CharT, char, std::mbstate_t> facet of the locale imbued in the stream.

Class std::collate encapsulates locale-specific collation (comparison) and hashing of strings. This facet is used by std::basic_regex and can be applied, by means of std::locale::operator(), directly to all standard algorithms that expect a string comparison predicate.
Class std::money_put encapsulates the rules for formatting monetary values as strings. The standard I/O manipulator std::put_money uses the std::money_put facet of the I/O stream's locale.

Class std::num_get encapsulates the rules for parsing string representations of numeric values. Specifically, types bool, unsigned short, unsigned int, long, unsigned long, long long, unsigned long long, float, double, long double, and void* are supported. The standard formatting input operators (such as cin >> n;) use the std::num_get facet of the I/O stream's locale to parse the text representations of the numbers.

Class std::num_put encapsulates the rules for formatting numeric values as strings. Specifically, the types bool, long, unsigned long, long long, unsigned long long, double, long double, void*, and of all types implicitly convertible to these (such as int or float) are supported. The standard formatting output operators (such as cout << n;) use the std::num_put facet of the I/O stream's locale to generate text representation of numbers.
Class Template which describes properties of a character type (class template)

Class ctype encapsulates character classification features. All stream input operations performed through std::basic_istream<charT> use the std::ctype<charT> of the locale imbued in the stream to identify whitespace characters for input tokenization. Stream output operations apply std::ctype<charT>::widen() to narrow-character arguments prior to output.
Class for representing and manipulating arrays of values
Class members cannot be captured explicitly by a capture without initializer (as mentioned above, only variables are permitted in the capture list):
Class template std::chrono::duration represents a time interval.
Class template std::chrono::time_point represents a point in time. It is implemented as if it stores a value of type Duration indicating the time interval from the start of the Clock's epoch.
Class template std::function is a general-purpose polymorphic function wrapper. Instances of std::function can store, copy, and invoke any Callable
Class template std::messages is a standard locale facet that encapsulates retrieval of strings from message catalogs, such as the ones provided by GNU gettext or by POSIX catgets.

Class template std::money_get encapsulates the rules for parsing monetary values from character streams. The standard I/O manipulator std::get_money uses the std::money_get facet of the I/O stream's locale.

Class template std::time_get encapsulates date and time parsing rules. The I/O manipulator std::get_time uses the std::time_get facet of the I/O stream's locale to convert text input to a std::tm object.

Class template std::time_put encapsulates date and time formatting rules. The I/O manipulator std::put_time uses the std::time_put facet of the I/O stream's locale to generate text representation of an std::tm object.
Class template std::tuple is a fixed-size collection of heterogeneous values. It is a generalization of std::pair.

Class template std::wstring_convert performs conversions between byte string std::string and wide string std::basic_string<Elem>, using an individual code conversion facet Codecvt. std::wstring_convert assumes ownership of the conversion facet, and cannot use a facet managed by a locale. The standard facets suitable for use with std::wstring_convert are std::codecvt_utf8 for UTF-8/UCS2 and UTF-8/UCS4 conversions and std::codecvt_utf8_utf16 for UTF-8/UTF-16 conversions.
Class template argument deduction is only performed if no template argument list is present. If a template argument list is specified, deduction does not take place.
Class template argument deduction of aggregates typically requires deduction guides:
Class template representing a text string object (class template)
Classes and structs are user-defined types, defined by class-specifier, which appears in decl-specifier-seq of the declaration syntax. The class specifier has the following syntax:
Classes derived from std::basic_streambuf are permitted to provide more efficient implementations of this function.

Classes that have custom destructors, copy/move constructors or copy/move assignment operators should deal exclusively with ownership (which follows from the Single Responsibility Principle). Other classes should not have custom destructors, copy/move constructors or copy/move assignment operators.[1]

Classes that manage non-copyable resources through copyable handles may have to declare copy assignment and copy constructor private and not provide their definitions or define them as deleted. This is another application of the rule of three: deleting one and leaving the other to be implicitly-defined will most likely result in errors.
Classes with open()/close(), lock()/unlock(), or init()/copyFrom()/destroy() member functions are typical examples of non-RAII classes:
Classes, algorithms and iterators to support regular expression processing

Classes, functions, variables, and member template specializations can be explicitly instantiated from their templates. Member functions, member classes, and static data members of class templates can be explicitly instantiated from their member definitions.
Classifies the wide character wc using the current C locale's LC_CTYPE category identified by desc.
Clears the state of the error condition. Sets the error code to 0 and error category to std::generic_category.
Clears the stored pathname. empty() is true after the call.
Closes the given file stream. Any unwritten buffered data are flushed to the OS. Any unread buffered data are discarded.
Closure types are not DefaultConstructible. Closure types have a deleted(until C++14)no(since C++14) default constructor.
Code that relies on some particular implementation option (e.g. int n = std::ios_base::hex), is nonportable because std::ios_base::fmtflags is not necessarily implicitly convertible to int.

Collating elements are the symbols found in POSIX regular expressions between [. and .]. For example, [.a.] matches the character a in the C locale. [.tilde.] matches the character ~ in the C locale as well. [.ch.] matches the digraph ch in Czech locale, but generates std::regex_error with error code std::regex_constants::error_collate in most other locales.
Collation order is the dictionary order: the position of the letter in the national alphabet (its

Comments serve as a sort of in-code documentation. When inserted into a program, they are effectively ignored by the compiler; they are solely intended to be used as notes by the humans that read source code. Although specific documentation is not part of the C++ standard, several utilities exist that parse comments with different documentation formats.
Common technique for algorithm selection based on iterator category tags is to use a dispatcher function (the alternative is std::enable_if).
Commonly overloaded operators have the following typical, canonical forms:[1]
Commutativity is satisfied, i.e. for any two types T and U, is_same<T, U>::value == true if and only if is_same<U, T>::value == true.
Compare *this with other for identity - memory allocated using a monotonic_buffer_resource can only be deallocated using that same resource.
Compare *this with other for identity - memory allocated using a synchronized_pool_resource can only be deallocated using that same resource.
Compare *this with other for identity - memory allocated using a unsynchronized_pool_resource can only be deallocated using that same resource.
Compare a basic_string object and null-terminated array of T
Compare a shared_ptr with a null pointer
Compare two bitsets to determine if they are identical:
Compare was required to be a strict weak ordering
Compare-and-exchange operations are often used as basic building blocks of lockfree data structures.
Compares *this for equality with other. Two memory_resources compare equal if and only if memory allocated from one memory_resource can be deallocated from the other and vice versa.
Compares lhs.first and rhs.first by calling the stored comparator.
Compares lhs and rhs using owner-based semantics. Effectively calls lhs.owner_before(rhs).
Compares a std::function with a null pointer. Empty functions (that is, functions without a callable target) compare equal, non-empty functions compare non-equal.
Compares a sub_match to another sub_match, a string, a null-terminated character sequence or a character.
Compares at most count characters of two null-terminated byte strings. The comparison is done lexicographically.
Compares at most count wide characters of two null-terminated wide strings. The comparison is done lexicographically.
Compares each value within the numeric array with another value.
Compares the memory_resources a and b for equality. Two memory_resources compare equal if and only if memory allocated from one memory_resource can be deallocated from the other and vice versa.
Compares the contents of a string with another string or a null-terminated array of CharT.
Compares the contents of the underlying containers of two container adaptors. The comparison is done by applying the corresponding operator to the underlying containers.
Compares the contents of two arrays.
Compares the contents of two containers.
Compares the contents of two unordered containers.
Compares the date and time represented by the objects x and y.
Compares the first count characters of the character strings s1 and s2. The comparison is done lexicographically.
Compares the first count wide characters of the wide character arrays pointed to by lhs and rhs. The comparison is done lexicographically.
Compares the lexical representations of the path and another path.
Compares the path with the directory entry rhs.
Compares the pointer values of two unique_ptrs, or a unique_ptr and nullptr.
Compares the two link objects x and y by name.
Compares the two time_zone objects x and y by name.
Compares the two year_month_day objects x and y. This is a lexicographical comparison: the year() is compared first, then month(), then day().
Compares the two year_month_day_last objects x and y. This is a lexicographical comparison: the year() is compared first, then month().
Compares the two zoned_time objects x and y. Two zoned_time objects compare equal if their time points and time zone pointers both compare equal according to operator==.
Compares the underlying iterators. Inverse comparisons are applied in order to take into account that the iterator order is reversed.
Compares two shared_ptr<T> objects or compares shared_ptr<T> with a null pointer.
Compares two complex numbers. Scalar arguments are treated as complex numbers with the real part equal to the argument and the imaginary part set to zero.
Compares two default allocators. Since default allocators are stateless, two default allocators are always equal.
Compares two distribution objects. Two distribution objects are equal when parameter values and internal state is the same.
Compares two null-terminated byte strings according to the current locale as defined by the LC_COLLATE category.
Compares two null-terminated byte strings lexicographically.
Compares two null-terminated wide strings according to the locale most recently installed by std::setlocale, as defined by the LC_COLLATE category.
Compares two null-terminated wide strings lexicographically.
Compares two polymorphic allocators. Two polymorphic allocators compare equal if their underlying memory resource compares equal.

Compares two pseudo-random number engine adaptors. Two engine adaptors are equal, if their underlying engines are equal and their internal state (if any) is equal, that is, if they would generate equivalent values for any number of calls of operator().
Compares two pseudo-random number engines. Two engines are equal, if their internal states are equivalent, that is, if they would generate equivalent values for any number of calls of operator().
Compares two scoped allocator adaptors. Two such allocators are equal if:

Compares two string arguments s1 and s2 according to the lexicographic comparison rules defined by this locale's std::collate<charT> facet. This operator allows any locale object that has a collate facet to be used as a binary predicate in the standard algorithms (such as std::sort) and ordered containers (such as std::set).
Compares two time points. The comparison is done by comparing the results time_since_epoch() for the time points.
Compares two values using 3-way comparison and produces a result of type std::partial_ordering.
Compares two values using 3-way comparison and produces a result of type std::strong_equality.
Compares two values using 3-way comparison and produces a result of type std::strong_ordering.
Compares two values using 3-way comparison and produces a result of type std::weak_equality.
Compares two values using 3-way comparison and produces a result of type std::weak_ordering.
Compares two values using three-way comparison and produces a result of the strongest applicable comparison category type.
Comparison between pointers and null pointer constants was removed in C++14.

Comparison operators are defined between values of this type and literal 0. This supports the expressions a <=> b == 0 and a <=> b != 0 used to convert the result of a three-way comparison operator to a boolean relationship; see std::is_eq and std::is_neq.

Comparison operators are defined between values of this type and literal 0. This supports the expressions a <=> b == 0 or a <=> b < 0 that can be used to convert the result of a three-way comparison operator to a boolean relationship; see std::is_eq, std::is_lt, etc.
Comparison operators are overloaded for many classes in the standard library.

Comparison operators can be used to compare two pointers (or pointers-to-members, for operator== and operator!= only), or a pointer to member(since C++14) and a null pointer constant, or two null pointer constants (but only as long as at least one of them is std::nullptr_t: comparison of NULL and NULL follows arithmetic comparison rules)(until C++14).
Compatibility header, in C defines true, false and bool which are keywords in C++.
Compatibility header, in C defines alternative operator representations which are keywords in C++.
Compilation takes place: each preprocessing token is converted to a token. The tokens are syntactically and semantically analyzed and translated as a translation unit.

Compilers may issue warnings on fallthrough (reaching the next case label without a break) unless the attribute [[fallthrough]] appears immediately before the case label to indicate that the fallthrough is intentional.
Compilers may issue warnings when an expression other than cast to void discards a value declared [[nodiscard]].
Complete objects, member objects, and array elements are also known as
Compound types are the types that are constructed from fundamental types. Any C++ type is either fundamental or compound.
Compute base-e exponential of z, that is

Compute the associated types of an iterator. The exposition-only concept dereferenceable is satisfied if and only if the expression *std::declval<T&>() is valid and has a referenceable type (in particular, not void).
Computes absolute value of each element in the value array.

Computes an exclusive prefix sum operation using binary_op (or std::plus<>() for overloads (1-2)) for the range [first, last), using init as the initial value, and writes the results to the range beginning at d_first. "exclusive" means that the i-th input element is not included in the i-th sum.

Computes an inclusive prefix sum operation using binary_op (or std::plus<>() for overloads (1-2)) for the range [first, last), using init as the initial value (if provided), and writes the results to the range beginning at d_first. "inclusive" means that the i-th input element is included in the i-th sum.
Computes both the quotient and the remainder of the division of the numerator x by the denominator y.
Computes complex arc cosine of a complex value z. Branch cuts exist outside the interval [−1 ; +1] along the real axis.
Computes complex arc hyperbolic cosine of a complex value z with branch cut at values less than 1 along the real axis.
Computes complex arc hyperbolic sine of a complex value z with branch cuts outside the interval [−i; +i] along the imaginary axis.
Computes complex arc sine of a complex value z. Branch cut exists outside the interval [−1 ; +1] along the real axis.
Computes complex arc tangent of a complex value z. Branch cut exists outside the interval [−i ; +i] along the imaginary axis.
Computes complex common (base 10) logarithm of a complex value z with a branch cut along the negative real axis.
Computes complex cosine of a complex value z.
Computes complex hyperbolic cosine of a complex value z.
Computes complex hyperbolic sine of a complex value z.
Computes complex hyperbolic tangent of a complex value z.
Computes complex sine of a complex value z.
Computes complex tangent of a complex value z.
Computes difference between two calendar times as std::time_t objects (time_end - time_beg) in seconds. If time_end refers to time point before time_beg then the result is negative.
Computes inner product (i.e. sum of products) or performs ordered map/reduce operation on the range [first1, last1) and the range beginning at first2.

Computes symmetric difference of two sorted ranges: the elements that are found in either of the ranges, but not in both of them are copied to the range beginning at d_first. The resulting range is also sorted.
Computes the absolute value of an integer number. The behavior is undefined if the result cannot be represented by the return type.
Computes the associated difference type of the type I, if any. Users may specialize incrementable_traits for a program-defined type.
Computes the associated value type of the type I, if any. Users may specialize readable_traits for a program-defined type.
Computes the complex arc hyperbolic tangent of z with branch cuts outside the interval [−1; +1] along the real axis.

Computes the differences between the second and the first of each adjacent pair of elements of the range [first, last) and writes them to the range beginning at d_first + 1. An unmodified copy of *first is written to *d_first.
Computes the greatest common divisor of the integers m and n.
Computes the inverse tangent of y/x using the signs of arguments to correctly determine quadrant.
Computes the least common multiple of the integers m and n.
Computes the maximum value of the elements.
Computes the midpoint of the integers, floating-points, or pointers a and b.
Computes the minimum value of the elements.

Computes the partial sums of the elements in the subranges of the range [first, last) and writes them to the range beginning at d_first. The first version uses operator+ to sum up the elements, the second version uses the given binary function op, both applying std::move to their operands on the left hand side(since C++20).
Computes the square root of the complex number z with a branch cut along the negative real axis.
Computes the sum of the elements.

Computes the sum of the given value init and the elements in the range [first, last). The first version uses operator+ to sum up the elements, the second version uses the given binary function op, both applying std::move to their operands on the left hand side(since C++20).
Concatenates the current path and the argument.
Concatenates two path components using the preferred directory separator if appropriate (see operator/= for details).
Concepts cannot recursively refer to themselves and cannot be constrained:
Condition variables permit concurrent invocation of the wait, wait_for, wait_until, notify_one and notify_all member functions.
Conditionally compiled macro that compares its argument to zero
Conditionally-explicit constructors make it possible to construct a tuple in copy-initialization context using list-initialization syntax:

Conjunction is short-circuiting: if there is a template type argument Bi with bool(Bi::value) == false, then instantiating conjunction<B1, ..., BN>::value does not require the instantiation of Bj::value for j > i.

Consider first some scenarios where the argument-dependent lookup is not employed. For that, we use the call (f)(t). As described in ADL, wrapping the function name in parentheses is suppressing the argument-dependent lookup.

Consistent with the behavior of unions during aggregate initialization, a default-constructed variant holds a value of its first alternative, unless that alternative is not default-constructible (in which case the variant is not default-constructible either). The helper class std::monostate can be used to make such variants default-constructible.
Const aggregate types are not DefaultConstructible if any of their members is an object of non-class type.
Const non-class types are not DefaultConstructible.
Const reference to the requested character.
Constant LegacyRandomAccessIterator and ConstexprIterator(since C++20)that is a LiteralType(since C++17)

Constant initialization is performed after(until C++14)instead of(since C++14) zero initialization of the static and thread-local objects and before all other initialization. Only the following variables are constant initialized:
Constant on average, worst case linear in the size of the container.
Constant[1] if a.size() != b.size(), linear otherwise
Constexpr constructors are permitted for classes that aren't literal types. For example, the default constructor of std::unique_ptr is constexpr, allowing constant initialization.
Constexpr for swap and swap related functions
Construct an empty container using a Compare() as key_comp
Construct an empty container using a copy of c as key_comp
Construct an object of type T, using the elements of the tuple t as the arguments to the constructor.
Construct an object with a tuple of arguments
Construction of one-off basic_istringstream objects in a tight loop, such as when used for string conversion, may be significantly more costly than calling str to reuse the same object.
Construction of one-off basic_ostringstream objects in a tight loop, such as when used for string conversion, may be significantly more costly than calling str to reuse the same object.
Construction of one-off basic_stringstream objects in a tight loop, such as when used for string conversion, may be significantly more costly than calling str to reuse the same object.
Constructor is a special non-static member function of a class that is used to initialize objects of its class type.
Constructors (3-4) define implicit conversions from std::chrono::year_month_day_last and std::chrono::sys_days, respectively.
Constructors are declared using member function declarators of the following form:
Constructors do not have names, but the injected-class-name of the enclosing class is considered to name a constructor in constructor declarations and definitions.

Constructors have no names and cannot be called directly. They are invoked when initialization takes place, and they are selected according to the rules of initialization. The constructors without explicit specifier are converting constructors. The constructors with a constexpr specifier make their type a LiteralType. Constructors that may be called without any argument are default constructors. Constructors that take another object of the same type as the argument are copy constructors and move constructors.
Constructs a1 such that it equals the prior value of a. Does not throw exceptions. The value of a is unchanged and a1 == a.(since C++20)
Constructs a such that B(a)==b and A(b)==a. Does not throw exceptions. (Note: this implies that all allocators related by rebind maintain each other's resources, such as memory pools)
Constructs a such that it equals the prior value of A(b). Does not throw exceptions.
Constructs a closure: an unnamed function object capable of capturing variables in scope.

Constructs a std::regex_iterator object i as if by std::regex_iterator<BidirIt, CharT, traits> i(first, last, re, flags), and uses it to step through every match of re within the sequence [first,last).
Constructs a binary_negate function object with the stored predicate pred.
Constructs a boyer_moore_horspool_searcher by storing copies of pat_first, pat_last, hf, and pred, setting up any necessary internal data structures.
Constructs a boyer_moore_searcher by storing copies of pat_first, pat_last, hf, and pred, setting up any necessary internal data structures.
Constructs a default_searcher by storing copies of pat_first, pat_last, and pred.
Constructs a monotonic_buffer_resource. The constructors not taking a upstream memory resource pointer uses the return value of std::pmr::get_default_resource as the upstream memory resource.
Constructs a month_day_last object that represents the last day of the month m.
Constructs a month_weekday object that stores the monthm and the weekday_indexedwdi.
Constructs a month_weekday_last object that stores the monthm and the weekday_lastwdl.
Constructs a pointer_to_binary_function function object with the stored function f.
Constructs a pointer_to_unary_function function object with the stored function f.
Constructs a regex_error with a given ecode of type std::regex_constants::error_type .
Constructs a shared_lock, optionally locking the supplied mutex.
Constructs a std::function from a variety of sources.
Constructs a unary_negate function object with the stored predicate pred.
Constructs a unique_lock, optionally locking the supplied mutex.
Constructs a year_month_day_last object storing the year y and the month mdl.month(). The constructed object represents the last day of that year and month.
Constructs a year_month_weekday_last object storing the year y, the month m, and the weekday wdl.weekday(). The constructed object represents the last weekday of that year and month.
Constructs a zoned_time object, initializing the stored time zone pointer and time point according to the following table, where traits is std::chrono::zoned_traits<TimeZonePtr>:
Constructs a dereferenceable pointer or pointer-like object ("fancy pointer") to its argument.
Constructs a locale object which is a copy of *this except for the facet of type Facet, which is copied from other.
Constructs a new duration from one of several optional data sources.
Constructs a new enable_shared_from_this object. The private std::weak_ptr<T> member is value-initialized.
Constructs a new std::codecvt_byname facet for a locale with name.
Constructs a new std::codecvt_utf16 facet, passes the initial reference counter refs to the base class.
Constructs a new std::codecvt_utf8 facet, passes the initial reference counter refs to the base class.
Constructs a new std::codecvt_utf8_utf16 facet, passes the initial reference counter refs to the base class.
Constructs a new std::collate_byname facet for a locale with name.
Constructs a new std::ctype_byname facet for a locale with name.
Constructs a new std::messages_byname facet for a locale with name.
Constructs a new std::moneypunct_byname facet for a locale with name.
Constructs a new std::numpunct_byname facet for a locale with name.
Constructs a new std::time_get_byname facet for a locale with name.
Constructs a new std::time_put_byname facet for a locale with name.
Constructs a new time_point from one of several optional data sources.
Constructs a new bitset from one of several optional data sources:
Constructs a new container from a variety of data sources, optionally using a user supplied allocator alloc.
Constructs a new distribution object. (2) uses a and b as the distribution parameters, (3) uses params as the distribution parameters.
Constructs a new distribution object. (2) uses a and b as the distribution parameters. (3) uses params as the distribution parameters.
Constructs a new distribution object. (2) uses alpha and beta as the distribution parameters. (3) uses params as the distribution parameters.
Constructs a new distribution object. (2) uses k and p as the distribution parameters. (3) uses params as the distribution parameters.
Constructs a new distribution object. (2) uses lambda as the distribution parameter. (3) uses params as the distribution parameter.
Constructs a new distribution object. (2) uses m and n as the distribution parameters. (3) uses params as the distribution parameters.
Constructs a new distribution object. (2) uses m and s as the distribution parameters. (3) uses params as the distribution parameters.
Constructs a new distribution object. (2) uses mean and stddev as the distribution parameters. (3) uses params as the distribution parameters.
Constructs a new distribution object. (2) uses mean as the distribution parameter. (3) uses params as the distribution parameter.
Constructs a new distribution object. (2) uses n as the distribution parameter. (3) uses params as the distribution parameter.
Constructs a new distribution object. (2) uses p as the distribution parameter. (3) uses params as the distribution parameter.
Constructs a new distribution object. (2) uses t and p as the distribution parameters. (3) uses params as the distribution parameters.

Constructs a new filesystem error object. The error code is set to ec and optionally, the paths that were involved in the operation that resulted in the error, are set to p1 and p2. what() after construction returns a string that contains what_arg.
Constructs a new future error object containing the error code std::make_error_code(ec).
Constructs a new instance of std::bad_weak_ptr. what() returns an implementation-defined null-terminated byte string.
Constructs a new regular expression from a sequence of characters interpreted according to the flags f.
Constructs a path p from a UTF-8 encoded sequence of chars, supplied either as an std::string, or as std::string_view, or as a null-terminated multibyte string, or as a [first, last) iterator pair.
Constructs a raw pointer that references the same object as its pointer-like ("fancy pointer") argument.

Constructs a sorted range beginning at d_first consisting of elements that are found in both sorted ranges [first1, last1) and [first2, last2). If some element is found m times in [first1, last1) and n times in [first2, last2), the first std::min(m, n) elements will be copied from the first range to the destination range. The order of equivalent elements is preserved. The resulting range cannot overlap with either of the input ranges.
Constructs a sorted union beginning at d_first consisting of the set of elements present in one or both sorted ranges [first1, last1) and [first2, last2).

Constructs a tuple of references to the arguments in args suitable for forwarding as an argument to a function. The tuple has rvalue reference data members when rvalues are used as arguments, and otherwise has lvalue reference data members.
Constructs a tuple that is a concatenation of all tuples in args.

Constructs a value of type std::wctrans_t that describes a LC_CTYPE category of wide character mapping. It may be one of the standard mappings, or a locale-specific mapping, such as "tojhira" or "tojkana".

Constructs a value of type std::wctype_t that describes a LC_CTYPE category of wide character classification. It may be one of the standard classification categories, or a locale-specific category, such as "jkanji".
Constructs an std::error_code object from a value of type std::future_errc as if by:

Constructs an std::error_code object from a value of type std::io_errc as if by return std::error_code(static_cast<int>(e), std::iostream_category()). This function is called by the constructor of std::error_code when given an std::io_errc argument.
Constructs an std::error_condition object from a value of type std::future_errc as if by:
Constructs an std::error_condition object from a value of type std::io_errc as if by return std::error_condition(static_cast<int>(e), std::iostream_category()).
Constructs an any object containing an object of type T, passing the provided arguments to T's constructor.
Constructs an once_flag object. The internal state is set to indicate that no function has been called yet.
Constructs an empty container using a Compare() as key_comp and inserts all elements from the range [i; j)
Constructs an empty container using a copy of c as key_comp and inserts all elements from the range [i; j)
Constructs an empty container with an unspecified number of buckets, using hasher() as hash function and key_equal() as equality predicate
Constructs an empty container with at least n buckets, using hasher() as hash function and key_equal() as equality predicate
Constructs an empty container with at least n buckets, using the given hash function and key_equal() as equality predicate
Constructs an empty container with at least n buckets, using the given hash function and equality predicate
Constructs an empty container with at least n buckets, using the given hash function and equality predicate, and inserts elements from [i,j) into it.
Constructs an object in allocated storage

Constructs an object in allocated, but not initialized storage pointed to by p the provided constructor arguments. If the object is of type that itself uses allocators, or if it is std::pair, passes this->resource() down to the constructed object.

Constructs an object in allocated, but not initialized storage pointed to by p using OuterAllocator and the provided constructor arguments. If the object is of type that itself uses allocators, or if it is std::pair, passes InnerAllocator down to the constructed object.
Constructs an object of type basic_istream::sentry with automatic storage duration and with the noskipws argument set to false, which performs the following
Constructs an object of type basic_istream::sentry with automatic storage duration and with the noskipws argument set to true, which performs the following
Constructs an object of type basic_ostream::sentry with automatic storage duration, which performs the following
Constructs an object of type T and wraps it in a std::unique_ptr.
Constructs an object of type T in allocated uninitialized storage pointed to by p, using placement-new.
Constructs an object of type X in previously-allocated storage at the address pointed to by xptr, using args as the constructor arguments
Constructs new std::bad_cast object. The contents of the byte string returned by what() are implementation defined.
Constructs new std::bad_typeid object. The contents of the byte string returned by what() are implementation defined.
Constructs new bad_alloc object with an implementation-defined null-terminated byte string which is accessible through what().
Constructs new bad_array_new_length object with in implementation-defined null-terminated byte string which is accessible through what().
Constructs new shared_ptr from a variety of pointer types that refer to an object to manage.
Constructs new weak_ptr that potentially shares an object with r.
Constructs new container from a variety of data sources and optionally using user supplied allocator alloc or comparison function object comp.

Constructs new container from a variety of data sources. Optionally uses user supplied bucket_count as a minimal number of buckets to create, hash as the hash function, equal as the function to compare keys and alloc as the allocator.
Constructs new distribution object. (2) uses a and b as the distribution parameters, (3) uses params as the distribution parameters.
Constructs new distribution object. (2) uses p as the distribution parameter. (3) uses params as the distribution parameter.
Constructs new input/output strstream and its underlying std::strstreambuf.
Constructs new istrstream and its underlying std::strstreambuf.
Constructs new numeric array from various sources.
Constructs new output strstream and its underlying std::strstreambuf.
Constructs new piecewise constant distribution object.
Constructs new piecewise linear distribution object.
Constructs new string from a variety of data sources and optionally using user supplied allocator alloc.
Constructs new underlying container of the container adaptor from a variety of data sources.
Constructs the auto_ptr from a pointer that refers to the object to manage.
Constructs the contained value in-place. If *this already contains a value before the call, the contained value is destroyed by calling its destructor.
Constructs the default allocator. Since the default allocator is stateless, the constructors have no visible effect.
Constructs the exception object using message as explanation string which can later be retrieved using what().
Constructs the exception object with what_arg as explanatory string that can be accessed through what().
Constructs the exception object with what_arg as explanatory string that can be accessed through what() and value as the object that can be accessed through get().
Constructs the exception object. The explanatory string returned by what() is equivalent to that produced by os.str() after the following code:
Constructs the sequence container equal, element-wise, to the range [i,j)
Constructs the sequence container holding n copies of t
Constructs the type index from std::type_info object.
Container adaptors provide a different interface for sequential containers.
Container elements may not be modified (even by non const iterators) since modification could change an element's hash and corrupt the container.
Contiguous containers in the standard library
Convenience aliases for containers using polymorphic allocators
Convenience function for locating a time zone in the time zone database. Equivalent to std::chrono::get_tzdb().locate_zone(tz_name).
Convenience function for obtaining local time zone from the time zone database. Equivalent to std::chrono::get_tzdb().current_zone().
Conversion function can be a template member function, for example, std::auto_ptr<T>::operator auto_ptr<Y>. See member template and template argument deduction for applicable special rules.
Conversion function is declared like a non-static member function or member function template with no parameters, no explicit return type, and with the name of the form:

Conversion function to its own (possibly cv-qualified) class (or to a reference to it), to the base of its own class (or to a reference to it), and to the type void can be defined, but can not be executed as part of the conversion sequence, except, in some cases, through virtual dispatch:
Conversion function. Returns the wrapped value.

Conversion functions can be inherited and can be virtual, but cannot be static. A conversion function in the derived class does not hide a conversion function in the base class unless they are converting to the same type.

Conversion in the opposite direction, from a pointer to data member of a derived class to a pointer to data member of an unambiguous non-virtual base class, is allowed with static_cast and explicit cast, even if the base class does not have that member (but the most-derived class does, when the pointer is used for access):

Conversion in the opposite direction, from a pointer to member function of a derived class to a pointer to member function of an unambiguous non-virtual base class, is allowed with static_cast and explicit cast, even if the base class does not have that member function (but the most-derived class does, when the pointer is used for access):
Converted character or ch if no uppercase version is defined by the current C locale.
Converting to sys_days and back can be used to normalize a year_month_day that contains an invalid day but a valid year and month:
Converts *this to a std::chrono::time_point representing the same date as this year_month_day.

Converts *this to a std::chrono::time_point representing the same date as this year_month_day_last. This is equivalent to composing a year_month_day from year(), month() and day() and converting that year_month_day to the destination type.
Converts *this to a std::chrono::time_point representing the same date as this year_month_weekday.
Converts *this to a std::chrono::time_point representing the same date as this year_month_weekday_last.
Converts *this to an auto_ptr for a different type Y.
Converts ch to unsigned char and locates the first occurrence of that value in the initial count characters (each interpreted as unsigned char) of the object pointed to by ptr.
Converts t to a time point type, using the coarser precision of the two types.
Converts value into a character string by successively filling the range [first, last), where [first, last) is required to be a valid range.
Converts a std::chrono::duration to a duration of different type ToDuration.
Converts a std::chrono::time_point from one duration to another.
Converts a sys_timet to a utc_timeu that represents the same point in time.
Converts a utc_timet to a sys_time representing the same point in time (if possible).
Converts a UTF-32 character to its narrow multibyte representation.
Converts a character c to its equivalent in the current locale. The result is converted from char to character type used within the stream if needed.
Converts a character array literal to basic_string
Converts a current locale-specific character c to its standard equivalent. The result is converted from char_type to char if needed. If no conversion can be performed, the function returns dfault.

Converts a multibyte character string from the array whose first element is pointed to by src to its wide character representation. Converted characters are stored in the successive elements of the array pointed to by dst. No more than len wide characters are written to the destination array.
Converts a multibyte character whose first byte is pointed to by s to a wide character, written to *pwc if pwc is not null.
Converts a narrow multibyte character to UTF-16 character representation.
Converts a narrow multibyte character to UTF-16 encoding
Converts a narrow multibyte character to UTF-8 encoding.
Converts a narrow multibyte character to a wide character.
Converts a narrow multibyte character to its UTF-32 character representation.

Converts a null-terminated multibyte character sequence, which begins in the conversion state described by *ps, from the array whose first element is pointed to by *src to its wide character representation. If dst is not null, converted characters are stored in the successive elements of the wchar_t array pointed to by dst. No more than len wide characters are written to the destination array.

Converts a sequence of wide characters from the array whose first element is pointed to by *src to its narrow multibyte representation that begins in the conversion state described by *ps. If dst is not null, converted characters are stored in the successive elements of the char array pointed to by dst. No more than len bytes are written to the destination array.

Converts a sequence of wide characters from the array whose first element is pointed to by src to its narrow multibyte representation that begins in the initial shift state. Converted characters are stored in the successive elements of the char array pointed to by dst. No more than len bytes are written to the destination array.
Converts a single code point from UTF-8 to a narrow multibyte character representation.
Converts a single code point from variable-length 16-bit character representation (typically, UTF-16) to a narrow multibyte character representation.
Converts a value of int_type to char_type. If there are no equivalent value (such as when c is a copy of the eof value), the results are unspecified.

Converts a wide character wc to multibyte encoding and stores it (including any shift sequences) in the char array whose first element is pointed to by s. No more than MB_CUR_MAX characters are stored.
Converts a wide character to its narrow multibyte representation.
Converts all directory separators in the generic-format view of the path to the preferred directory separator.
Converts any type T to a reference type, making it possible to use member functions in decltype expressions without the need to go through constructors.
Converts between types by reinterpreting the underlying bit pattern.
Converts between types using a combination of explicit and implicit conversions.
Converts between types using a combination of implicit and user-defined conversions.
Converts between types with different cv-qualification.
Converts given calendar time std::tm to a textual representation of the following fixed 25-character form: Www Mmm dd hh:mm:ss yyyy\n.
Converts given time since epoch as std::time_t value into calendar time, expressed in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).
Converts given time since epoch as std::time_t value into calendar time, expressed in local time.
Converts given time since epoch to a calendar local time and then to a textual representation, as if by calling std::asctime(std::localtime(time)). The resulting string has the following format:
Converts local calendar time to a time since epoch as a time_t object. time->tm_wday and time->tm_yday are ignored. The values in time are permitted to be outside their normal ranges.
Converts the gps_timet to a utc_time representing the same point in time.
Converts the local_timetp in this time zone to the corresponding sys_time.
Converts the sys_timetp to the corresponding local_time in this time zone.
Converts the tai_timet to a utc_time representing the same point in time.
Converts the utc_timet to a gps_time representing the same point in time.
Converts the utc_timet to a tai_time representing the same point in time.
Converts the argument std::chrono::time_point to the destination clock.

Converts the calendar date and time stored in the std::tm object pointed to by t into a character string, according to the format string [fmtbeg, fmtend). The format string is the same as used by std::srtftime, but each format specifier is processed by an individual call to do_put(), which can be customized by extending this facet.
Converts the character ch to lowercase if possible, using the conversion rules specified by the given locale's std::ctype facet.
Converts the character ch to uppercase if possible, using the conversion rules specified by the given locale's std::ctype facet.
Converts the character sequence designated by the iterator range [F1, F2) into a value of a BitmaskType that can subsequently be passed to isctype
Converts the contents of the bitset to a string. Uses zero to represent bits with value of false and one to represent bits with value of true.
Converts the contents of the bitset to an unsigned long long integer.
Converts the contents of the bitset to an unsigned long integer.
Converts the date and time information from a given calendar time time to a null-terminated multibyte character string str according to format string format. Up to count bytes are written.
Converts the date and time information from a given calendar time time to a null-terminated wide character string str according to format string format. Up to count wide characters are written.
Converts the given character to lowercase according to the character conversion rules defined by the currently installed C locale.
Converts the given character to uppercase according to the character conversion rules defined by the currently installed C locale.
Converts the given wide character to lowercase, if possible.
Converts the given wide character to uppercase, if possible.
Converts the implementation-defined character string arg into the corresponding quiet NaN value, as if by calling std::strtod, std::strtof, or std::strtold, respectively, as follows:
Converts the time point t of a clock Source to an equivalent time point of the clock Dest, using std::chrono::system_clock and/or std::chrono::utc_clock as intermediaries if necessary.

Converts the value ch to unsigned char and copies it into each of the first count characters of the object pointed to by dest. If the object is a potentially-overlapping subobject or is not TriviallyCopyable (e.g., scalar, C-compatible struct, or an array of trivially copyable type), the behavior is undefined. If count is greater than the size of the object pointed to by dest, the behavior is undefined.
Converts to an object of the underlying std::basic_string type.
Copies 32-bit values to ob that would reproduce the current state of the object if passed to a constructor of S.
Copies count bytes from the object pointed to by src to the object pointed to by dest. Both objects are reinterpreted as arrays of unsigned char.
Copies count character from character string pointed to by src to character string pointed to by dest.
Copies count characters from the object pointed to by src to the object pointed to by dest. Both objects are reinterpreted as arrays of unsigned char.

Copies a substring [pos, pos+count) to character string pointed to by dest. If the requested substring lasts past the end of the string, or if count == npos, the copied substring is [pos, size()). The resulting character string is not null-terminated.
Copies a symlink to another location.
Copies at most count characters of the byte string pointed to by src (including the terminating null character) to character array pointed to by dest.
Copies at most count characters of the wide string pointed to by src (including the terminating null wide character) to wide character array pointed to by dest.
Copies correctly even where the ranges [p,p+n) and [s,s+n) overlap
Copies elements from the range [first, last), to another range beginning at d_first, omitting the elements which satisfy specific criteria. Source and destination ranges cannot overlap.
Copies exactly count successive wide characters from the wide character array pointed to by src to the wide character array pointed to by dest.

Copies exactly count successive wide characters from the wide character array pointed to by src to the wide character array pointed to by dest. If the objects overlap, the behavior is undefined. If count is zero, the function does nothing.
Copies files and directories, with a variety of options.
Copies the character string pointed to by src, including the null terminator, to the character array whose first element is pointed to by dest.

Copies the elements from the range [first, last) to another range beginning at d_first replacing all elements satisfying specific criteria with new_value. The source and destination ranges cannot overlap.

Copies the elements from the range [first, last), to another range beginning at d_first in such a way that there are no consecutive equal elements. Only the first element of each group of equal elements is copied.

Copies the elements from the range, defined by [first, last), to another range ending at d_last. The elements are copied in reverse order (the last element is copied first), but their relative order is preserved.
Copies the elements from the sorted range [first1, last1) which are not found in the sorted range [first2, last2) to the range beginning at d_first.
Copies the elements in the range, defined by [first, last), to another range beginning at d_first.
Copies the substring [pos, pos + rcount) to the character array pointed to by dest, where rcount is the smaller of count and size() - pos.
Copies the wide character ch into each of the first count wide characters of the wide character array pointed to by dest.
Copies the wide string pointed to by src (including the terminating null wide character) to wide character array pointed to by dest.
Copy assignment operator is deleted. monotonic_buffer_resource is not copy assignable
Copy assignment operator is deleted. synchronized_pool_resource is not copy assignable
Copy assignment operator is deleted. unsynchronized_pool_resource is not copy assignable
Copy assignment operator. Assigns the contents of other.
Copy assignment operator. Drops the current reference and stores a reference to other.get().
Copy assignment, also copies the hash function, predicate and maximum load factor

Copy constructors of AllocatorAwareContainers obtain their instances of the allocator by calling std::allocator_traits<allocator_type>::select_on_container_copy_construction on the allocator of the container being copied.
Copy constructors, also copies the hash function, predicate and maximum load factor

Copy elision is the only allowed form of optimization(until C++14)one of the two allowed forms of optimization, alongside allocation elision and extension,(since C++14) that can change the observable side-effects. Because some compilers do not perform copy elision in every situation where it is allowed (e.g., in debug mode), programs that rely on the side-effects of copy/move constructors and destructors are not portable.
Copy initialization is performed in the following situations:
Copy symlinks as symlinks, not as the files they point to
Copy the directory structure, but do not copy any non-directory files
Copy- or move-assigns another file status object.
Copy-assignment will replace the allocator only if std::allocator_traits<allocator_type>::propagate_on_container_copy_assignment::value is true
Copy-constructs a1 such that a1 == a. Does not throw exceptions. (Note: every Allocator also satisfies CopyConstructible)
Copy-initialization is less permissive than direct-initialization: explicit constructors are not converting constructors and are not considered for copy-initialization.

Copying a container using a polymorphic_allocator will not call the allocator's copy constructor. Instead, the new container will use the return value of select_on_container_copy_construction (a default-constructed polymorphic_allocator) as its allocator.

Copying an auto_ptr copies the pointer and transfers ownership to the destination: both copy construction and copy assignment of auto_ptr modify their right hand arguments, and the "copy" is not equal to the original. Because of these unusual copy semantics, auto_ptr may not be placed in standard containers. std::unique_ptr is preferred for this and other uses.(since C++11).
Core Issue 1776: Replacement of class objects containing reference members (std::launder)
Corner case platforms are also supported:
Coroutines cannot use variadic arguments, plain return statements, or placeholder return types (auto or Concept).

Correctly using reserve() can prevent unnecessary reallocations, but inappropriate uses of reserve() (for instance, calling it before every push_back() call) may actually increase the number of reallocations (by causing the capacity to grow linearly rather than exponentially) and result in increased computational complexity and decreased performance. For example, a function that receives an arbitrary vector by reference and appends elements to it should usually
Create a new polymorphic_allocator for use by a container's copy constructor
Creates a std::codecvt facet and forwards the starting reference count refs to the base class constructor, locale::facet::facet().
Creates a std::collate facet and forwards the starting reference count refs to the base class constructor, locale::facet::facet().
Creates a std::ctype<char> facet and forwards the starting reference count refs to the base class constructor, locale::facet::facet().
Creates a std::ctype facet and forwards the starting reference count refs to the base class constructor, locale::facet::facet().
Creates a std::messages facet and forwards the starting reference count refs to the base class constructor, locale::facet::facet().
Creates a std::money_get facet and forwards the starting reference count refs to the base class constructor, locale::facet::facet().
Creates a std::money_put facet and forwards the starting reference count refs to the base class constructor, locale::facet::facet().
Creates a std::moneypunct facet and forwards the starting reference count refs to the base class constructor, locale::facet::facet().
Creates a std::num_get facet and forwards the starting reference count refs to the base class constructor, locale::facet::facet().
Creates a std::num_put facet and forwards the starting reference count refs to the base class constructor, locale::facet::facet().
Creates a std::numpunct facet and forwards the starting reference count refs to the base class constructor, locale::facet::facet().
Creates a std::pair object, deducing the target type from the types of arguments.
Creates a std::time_get facet and forwards the starting reference count refs to the base class constructor, locale::facet::facet().
Creates a std::time_put facet and forwards the starting reference count refs to the base class constructor, locale::facet::facet().
Creates a std::array object from a built-in array
Creates a std::array object whose size and optionally element type are deduced from the arguments

Creates a copy of other, replacing the contents of *this. The reference counts of all facets held by other are incremented. The reference counts of all facets previously held by *this are decremented, and those facets whose reference count becomes zero are deleted.
Creates a forwarding call wrapper that returns the negation of the callable object it holds.
Creates a function object that returns the complement of the result of the function object it holds
